sentences.sentence: God and the Man
A man was once driving a heavy cart( 马车 ) along a muddy( 泥泞的 ) road.
At last( 最终 ), he came to a part of the road where the wheels got stuck( 陷入 ) in the mud( 泥浆 ).
The more the horses pulled, the deeper the wheels sank( 沉陷 ).
The man knelt down( 跪下 ) and prayed( 祈祷 ) to the god of strength,
“Please help me in this difficult time.”
But the god appeared to him and said, “Man, don’t kneel( 下跪 ) there.
Get up and put your shoulder to the wheel, and whip( 鞭打 ) your horses, and then you may call on( 呼吁 ) me to help you.
But if you won’t lift a finger to help yourself, you can’t expect me, or anyone else, to help you.”
MORAL: The gods help those who help themselves.
The Gnat( 飞虫 ) and the Bull( 公牛 )
A gnat( 飞虫 ) landed on( 降落 ) one of the horns( 角 ) of a Bull( 公牛 ), and remained sitting there for a long time.
When it had rested enough and was about to( 即将 ) fly away, it said to the bull( 公牛 ), “Do you mind if I go now?”
The bull( 公牛 ) merely raised his eyes and said, without interest,
“I don’t care; I didn’t notice when you came, and I shan’t know when you go away.”
MORAL: We often imagine that others are thinking about us more than they really are.
The Gnat( 飞虫 ) and the Lion
A gnat( 飞虫 ) came to the lion and said, “I am not afraid of you, and you are not more powerful than me.
What kind of power do you have?
The fact that you can scratch( 挠 ) with your claws( 爪子 ) and bite with your teeth?
Even women do that when they argue with their husbands!
I am far stronger than you are, and to prove( 证明 ) it, I challenge( 向...挑战 ) you to a fight!”
The gnat( 飞虫 ) gave his battle-cry and then attacked, biting the lion around the nose in the places where the lion had no hair.
While trying to hit the gnat( 飞虫 ), the lion only hurt himself with his claws( 爪子 ), until he finally admitted( 承认 ) that the gnat( 飞虫 ) had won.
Having won his battle with the lion, the gnat( 飞虫 ) gave his battle-cry again and sang a song to celebrate his victory.
He then flew away—only to get caught in the web( 网 ) of a spider( 蜘蛛 ).
As he was being eaten by the spider( 蜘蛛 ), the gnat( 飞虫 ) regretted the fact that while he had done battle with the mighty lion,
he was about to be killed by a stupid little insect( 昆虫 ).
MORAL: Don’t let your successes make you over-confident( 过于自信的 ).
The Goat( 山羊 ) and the Wolf( 狼 )
A goat( 山羊 ), returning without protection from the field, was chased( 追赶 ) by a wolf( 狼 ).
Seeing he could not get away, he turned round, and said,
“I know, friend, that I must be your dinner.
Before I die, I would ask you one favor( 帮忙 ).
Will you play a song for me to dance to.”
The wolf( 狼 ) agreed, and while he was playing, the goat( 山羊 ) was dancing.
Some dogs heard the sound, and began chasing( 追赶 ) the wolf( 狼 ).
Turning to the goat( 山羊 ), he said,
“It is just what I deserve( 应得 ).
I, who am only a killer, should not have played music to please you.”
MORAL: Stick to( 坚持 ) what you do best.

article_info.previous: 在昨天的故事里，不自量力的老青蛙不断地鼓自己的肚皮，想和一头牛比大小，最终爆体而亡。这个故事告诉我们人要量力而行，自负可能会带来很严重的后果。
article_info.share_words: The gods help those who help themselves. Stick to what you do best.

question.cn: 在故事 God and the Man中，上帝给了那个人什么建议？
question.en: In the story God and the Man, which piece of advice did God give the man?

options.en: Help himself before asking for help.

analysis: 文中God对那个人说：“ Get up and put your shoulder to the wheel, and whip your horses, and then you may call on me for help you.”上帝的意思是让他先自己帮助自己再去求助，因此选A。

question.cn: 在故事The Gnat and the Bull中，公牛对飞虫的态度是什么？
question.en: In the story The Gnat and the Bull, what was the bull's attitude towards the gnat?

options.en: The bull was indifferent to the gnat.

analysis: 文中提到：“The bull merely raised his eyes and said, without interest, ‘I don't care; I didn't notice when you came, and I shan't know when you go away.’”所以公牛根本不会关心飞虫做什么，因此选C。

question.cn: 在故事The Gnat and the Lion中，飞虫和狮子的战斗谁赢了？
question.en: In the story The Gnat and the Lion, what was the result of the battle between the gnat and the lion?

analysis: 文中提到：“While trying to hit the gnat, the lion only hurt himself out with his claws, until he finally admitted that the gnat had won.” 可知，最后飞虫赢了，因此选A。

question.cn: 在故事The Gnat and the Lion中，飞虫在与狮子的战斗之后，发生了什么？
question.en: In the story The Gnat and the Lion, what happened to the gnat after the battle?

options.cn: 他取代狮子成为动物之王。
options.en: He replaced the lion to be the King of animals.
He was eaten by a spider.
He was eaten by the lion.

analysis: 文中提到：“He then flew away-only to get caught in the web of a spider, as he was being eaten by the spider.”可知飞虫在与狮子的战斗之后被蜘蛛吃了，因此选B。

question.cn: 在故事The Goat and the Wolf中，最后狼有没有吃到羊？
question.en: In the story The Goat and the Wolf, did the wolf eat the goat?

analysis: 文中提到：“Some dogs heard the sound, and began chasing the wolf.”可知，最后狼被牧羊犬追赶，所以没有吃到羊，因此选B。

share_title: 100天读完3本英文书，今天是第13天
